text:
@Michael Deierhoi  
What do you think happens to those heat trapping gasses once they are released? Do you think they just sit there and accumulate?
We are in a symbiotic relationship with the flora of this planet. Did you know before we started pumping Co2 into the atmosphere our earth was on the verge of an ecological collapse? Co2 levels had gotten so low that all the life that depends on it was in danger of a great die off, an extinction event. And we would have gone with them because we need the oxygen they produce. And oxygen being as highly reactive as it is, does not last long in the atmosphere unless it is constantly replenished. Plus, right now Co2 levels are only at six percent in our atmosphere. Simply because most of it gets scrubbed out by the trillions of green and growing things that depends on it to survive. Plus there is the fact that every drop of rain that falls, every snowflake has Co2 trapped in it, and all the rivers lakes and streams, as well as all the oceans absorb Co2 the same way they absorb oxygen. Billions of tons of Co2 gets scrubbed out by this manner every year. Don't let the alarmists play you for the fool.
Earth has been hotter than this in the past, and we weren't there to make it happen, and most everything survived it.
Life will survive.

Those levels when compared to everything else are still miniscule. Since you mentioned it.
We have been coming out of the last ice for ten thousand years. Yet it hasn't accured to you or anyone else that this warming trend is perfectly natural? It is pure ego to think that we can have any effect on a system that is so large.
Here is something to contemplate. 
Earth has its annual seasons of spring, summer, fall, and winter.
It also has geological seasons that last thousands of years. We just came out of the geological winter known as the last ice. We have reached or are nearing the end of the geological spring. What happens in the summer? It continues to warm up right to August, the hottest month of the year. So tighten your seat belt baby. Earth is going to continue to get warmer and there is not a damn thing we can do about it.
Did you know that at one time earth was so hot that it enjoyed tropical temperatures at the poles?
And we were not there to influence that warming trend. And according to geologists and meteorologists I know. This is the coolest interglacial period so far.
author: Randy Powell

text:
@Randy Powell  What I see in your comments are the same AGW denier perspectives I have heard before like how could such a minuscule amount of CO2 lead to a warming climate.  What you misunderstand about that  statement is that the amount of CO2 added to the atmosphere has gradually increased over the last 200 years and as that CO2 increased so too has their ability to retain heat.  And CO2 is known to stay in the atmosphere for at least 100 years vs CH4 which degrades in about 10 years.  And much of CH4 also degrades into CO2. .

Of course some of is processed by plants but the vast percentage remains in the atmosphere.  

A great deal of CO2 is also absorbed by the oceans and plants, but can only which can only hold so much CO2 as a free molecule.  Most is transformed into carbonic acid which has lowered the ph in the oceans.  This has increased the stress to much of the sea which is too extensive to address here.  

You also make tangential statements like the point that Antarctica was at one time completely ice free.  My first response is So What?? That was tens of millions of years ago.  Humans probably couldn't even survive for very long in such an environment.   

This is clearly a issue that we will never agree on.  From my perspective as long as you subscribe to the AGW denier narrative then is no chance I could ever PROVE to you the global warming is real.   It reminds me of the many Americans who are dying from Covid in the hospital and were still in denial to their doctors that they were dying from Covid!!

text:
@Michael Deierhoi  
But for my part. It doesn't matter that it stays in the atmosphere for 100 years. Because every second, of every day, an equal amount is still being scrubbed out through natural processes. Just like rotating and restocking the shelves at the grocery store. Old stuff goes away, new stuff is added. It is a self governing system.

text: Glaciers are retreating much faster in the last 100 years then at any time in the last several thousand years at least.  Ice cores are often used to determine how old glaciers.   Glaciers are also melting at a record pace in Greenland and Antarctica.
author: Michael Deierhoi

text:
@Michael Deierhoi  
Ice core dating is in a bit of a crisis to put it mildly, putting old claims and assumptions well into the discard pile and everything else on rethink. The observational data we have on glaciers over the last 100 years covers less than 10% of existing glaciers and of those as many have advanced as those receding. Coastal glaciers in Greenland have been melting in recent years while the ice mass of Greenland overall has been gaining hundreds if not thousands of metric tons every year without fail as long as we’ve had the technology to make that calculation. The only melting going on in Antarctica is ocean ice shelf over recently discovered volcanic activity, not glacial.

text:
@Karl Lieber  What I am aware of is the reality of global warming has resulted in numerous negative consequences for the world and these consequences are becoming more and more apparent.

Increasing size and strength of hurricanes as a direct consequence of warming sea surface temperatures.

Receding Arctic Ice cap secondary to accelerated warming in the Arctic.

The majority of glaciers around the world receding again because of increasing global temperatures.

Increasing warming of the oceans because of the atmospheric warming contributes to ripple effect of countless negative consequences for wildlife, bleaching of coral reefs and so on.  

Increasing acidity of the oceans because of increased atmospheric CO2 has resulted in the decline of coral reefs and the threat to shell fish.

The continued over fishing by countries around the world which is depleting some fish stocks to dangerously low levels.

The over use of pesticides and habitat destruction which is killing insects on a massive  scale which in turns negatively affects birds which are also seeing precipitous declines.
I am an avid birder and insect photographer and have seen the dramatic decline of insects and birds myself.   

There many, many more examples how global warming and other human threats to life on earth are beginning to come back and seriously affect the quality of life on this rock.   My efforts are wholly inadequate, but I speak to this crisis when ever I can and to who ever will listen.

text:
@Michael Deierhoi  
Let me rephrase what you just asked.

"If it isn't climate change causing climate what's causing climate change?"

The question makes no sense but I digress.

The Arctic sea ice and greenland Ice sheet has gotten smaller because of global warming, both induced by humans and natural factors.

Hurricanes haven't gotten stronger or bigger, hurricanes of all strengths and sizes have declined in frequency in every oceanic basin except the Indian ocean. Smaller weaker storms are declining at a faster rate than larger stronger storms, increasing the average intensity. But stronger and bigger storms are in no way becoming more frequent. This decline though is likely attributable to increased wind shear caused by global waming, which tears apart weaker storms.

text:
@Darren C  A bit of sarcasm hmmmm??  Climate scientists never said climate change is only caused by humans.  Climate change, which is both warming or cooling globally over extended periods of time.  

The so called Milankovitch Cycles alter the eccentricity and tilt of the earth which has led to the ebb and flow of the ice ages, but those changes occured over thousands of years.  We are between cycles at this point and no warming is imminent from these cycles nor is another ice age coming soon.  

In fact the elevated CO2 and CH4 in the atmosphere is likely delaying the next age for an indefinite time.   When the ice ages occured CO2 was at 270 ppm and dropped to as low as 190 ppm.  But now CO2 pushing up toward 420 ppm making an ice age very unlikely.  And no the Grand Solar Minimum won't bring even a little ice age for the same reason.  
Science!!  Gotta love it!!
